Á¨¨97Êù°=>@linseymarr These papers show that covid-19 survival on surfaces (up to days) can be up to an order of magnitude higher than the survival in aerosols (hours). Survival of influenza in aerosols is up to 1 hour or less.
https://t.co/WWjxv1V99H
https://t.co/n

Á¨¨8Êù°=>Our results indicate that aerosol and fomite transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is plausible, since the virus can remain viable and infectious in aerosols for hours and on surfaces up to days. https://t.co/wpF5tj6hVb
Á¨¨9Êù°=>The longest viability of both viruses was on stainless steel and plastic; the estimated median half-life of SARS-CoV-2 was approximately 5.6 hours on stainless steel and 6.8 hours on plastic. https://t.co/wpF5tj6hVb
Á¨¨10Êù°=>On copper, no viable SARS-CoV-2 was measured after 4 hours and no viable SARS-CoV-1 was measured after 8 hours. https://t.co/wpF5tj6hVb
Á¨¨11Êù°=>SARS-CoV-2 was more stable on plastic and stainless steel than on copper and cardboard, and viable virus was detected up to 72 hours after application to these surfaces https://t.co/wpF5tj6hVb
Á¨¨12Êù°=>SARS-CoV-2 remained viable in aerosols throughout the duration of our experiment (3 hours), with a reduction in infectious titer from 103.5¬†to 102.7¬†TCID50¬†per liter of air. https://t.co/wpF5tj6hVb

Á¨¨74Êù°=>Current official advice in Germany on survival of #coronavirus on surfaces:

- 3 hours as aerosol in air
- 2 - 3 days on metal and plastic
- 24 hours on carton box/paper
- 4 hours on copper

Source: https://t.co/eFxynXUhWx citing https://t.co/1rEpApeTzu.
